plants.name: Rosa chinensis
plants.description: A popular garden rose species known for its recurrent blooming habit and delicate fragrant flowers. It features a classic rose shape and is one of the ancestors of modern garden roses.
plants.bloomingSeason: Late spring to summer (May to August)
plants.location: Widely cultivated in temperate to subtropical regions worldwide, native to Southwest China
plants.funFact: The China Rose is one of the few rose species that bloom repeatedly throughout the growing season, unlike many wild roses that bloom only once.

plants.name: Lupinus perennis
plants.description: A perennial herbaceous plant that produces tall spikes of pea-like flowers. It is vital for the Karner blue butterfly which relies on it as its larval host plant.
plants.bloomingSeason: Late spring to early summer (May to July)
plants.location: Eastern North America, particularly in sandy soils and pine barrens
plants.funFact: Wild Lupine fixes nitrogen in the soil through a symbiotic relationship with bacteria, enriching nutrient-poor environments.

plants.name: Erythrina crista-galli
plants.description: A striking flowering tree or shrub admired for its vibrant red, uniquely shaped flowers resembling a rooster's crest; culturally significant in South America.
plants.bloomingSeason: Late spring to summer (November to March in Southern Hemisphere, so June flowering is more typical in Northern Hemisphere botanical gardens)
plants.location: Native to South America (Argentina, Uruguay, Brazil), cultivated in subtropical regions worldwide
plants.funFact: Erythrina flowers attract hummingbirds and have adapted their shape for pollination by these birds.

plants.name: Digitalis purpurea
plants.description: Biennial herbaceous plant with tall spikes of tubular flowers that are highly attractive to bees, used medicinally as a source of cardiac glycosides.
plants.bloomingSeason: Late spring to summer (May to August)
plants.location: Native to Europe but widely naturalized in North America and other temperate regions
plants.funFact: Foxglove's cardiac glycosides (digoxin) have been used medicinally to treat heart conditions, but the plant is toxic if ingested improperly.
